about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
In 2016, Singhal et al developed criteria for prompt bedside diagnosis of reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndromes (RCVS) and primary angiitis of the central nervous system (PACNS).

Study Population: 206 patients (159 RCVS to 47 PACNS patients).

Findings: Recurrent thunderclap headache or single thunderclap headache plus either normal parenchymal neuroimaging, normal neurovascular imaging becoming abnormal within days, border zone infarcts, or vasogenic edema were predictive of RCVS. The presence of deep brainstem infarcts or abnormal CSF were specific for PACNS.

Strengths:

  • Large cohort of patients compared to prior case series. 
  • These findings have been externally validated (de Boysson 2018).

Limitations: Retrospective, single center study (Massachusetts General Hospital) that may bias towards a more severe presentation.

In 2019, Rocha et al developed a method that could accurately distinguish RCVS from other intracranial arteriopathies upon admission, using widely available clinical and imaging features - the RCVS2 Score.

Study Population: 110 patients from the Massachusetts General Hospital’s Research Patient Database Repository 18-55 years old.

Findings:

  • For score ≥5: specificity 99%, sensitivity 90%, PPV 96%, NPV 96%

  • For score ≤2: specificity 100%, sensitivity 85%, PPV 100%, NPV 71%

Strengths:

  • Novel – there are no other scores for diagnostic decision making in RCVS. 

  • Validated in a cohort of patients with primary angiitis of the CNS, the closest mimic of RCVS.

Limitations:

  • All patients admitted to a single stroke referral center and may reflect more severe cases of disease, which can limit generalizability. 

  • Only validated against a cohort of patients with PACNS and requires validation in other arteriopathies and external validation.
about.formula_en:
Addition of the selected points:

Variable Points
Recurrent or single thunderclap headache Present 5
Absent 0
Intracranial carotid artery involvement Affected -2
Not affected 0
Vasoconstrictive trigger identified Yes 3
No 0
Sex Female 1
Male 0
Subarachnoid hemorrhage present on imaging Present 1
Absent 0

Original/Primary Reference.text: Rocha EA, Topcuoglu MA, Silva GS, Singhal AB. RCVS2 score and diagnostic approach for reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome. Neurology. 2019;92(7):e639-e647.

Other References.text: Singhal AB, Topcuoglu MA, Fok JW, et al. Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndromes and primary angiitis of the central nervous system: clinical, imaging, and angiographic comparison. Ann Neurol. 2016;79(6):882-894.

Validation.text: de Boysson H, Parienti J-J, Mawet J, et al. Primary angiitis of the CNS and reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome: A comparative study. Neurology. 2018;91(16):e1468-e1478.

expert_name: Jose Biller, MD, FACP, FAAN, FANA, FAHA

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Detailed history-taking is imperative, with clear characterization of the hyperacute onset of severe headache and identification of vasoconstrictive triggers. 
  • Failure to identify a trigger that is present may change the diagnosis from RCVS to non-RCVS arteriopathy. Clinical judgment should be used when identifying triggers since vasoconstrictive potency can vary and a temporal relationship may be important.
  • A new angiographic abnormality (CTA, MRA, or catheter cerebral angiogram) is required to apply the RCVS2 score.
  • Intermediate scores of 3-4 were equivocal with a sensitivity of 10% and specificity of 86% for diagnosing RCVS.
  • RCVS may have normal intracranial vascular imaging early or late in the course, in which case the RCVS2 score is inapplicable. 
  • Not applicable to children <18 or adults >55.
  • Note that intracranial internal carotid artery narrowing scores negative points (-2) to avoid misdiagnosis in patients with Moyamoya disease.
how_to_use.use_case_en: Use in patients 18-55 years old with a new presentation of intracranial arteriopathy on intracranial vascular imaging to differentiate RCVS from non-RCVS causes of intracranial arteriopathy.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• Provides a discriminatory clinical tool using variables that are readily available at first presentation.
  • Early distinction between RCVS and non-RCVS arteriopathies is diagnostically challenging and has important management implications particularly because steroids, often used in non-RCVS arteriopathies, worsen outcomes in RCVS. 
  • A score ≥5 diagnosed RCVS with 90% sensitivity and 99% specificity. A score ≤2 excluded RCVS with 85% sensitivity and 100% specificity.
  • Accurately distinguishes RCVS from its closest mimic, primary angiitis of the CNS (PACNS).

next_steps.advice_en:
• Score ≥5: a diagnosis of RCVS is highly likely. 
  • Score ≤2: a diagnosis of RCVS is highly unlikely and non-RCVS arteriopathy should be considered in the appropriate clinical context. 
  • Score 3-4: diagnosis is equivocal and a bedside clinical approach is recommended. Other clinical features that independently suggest RCVS include recurrent thunderclap headache, presence of a trigger with normal brain parenchymal imaging, and convexity SAH.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: Only apply to patients with new onset arteriopathy on intracranial vascular imaging.
next_steps.management_en: If RCVS is likely, avoid steroids as these may worsen outcomes. In addition, avoid vasoconstrictive medications such as sumatriptan.

calc.full_title_en: RCVS<sub>2</sub> Score for Reversible Cerebral Vasoconstriction Syndrome
calc.instructions_en: To use the score, patients must have a first presentation of abnormal intracranial vascular imaging and be 18–55 years old. The score has not been tested outside this age range.
calc.medium_description_en: Distinguishes reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome from other intracranial arteriopathies at admission.

seo.keywords_en: RCVS2 Score for Reversible Cerebral Vasoconstriction Syndrome, RCVS2 Score, reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome, rcvs, arteriopathy, cerebral vasoconstriction, arteriopathies, rcvs2, intracranial arteriopathies
seo.meta_description_en: RCVS2 Score for Reversible Cerebral Vasoconstriction Syndrome diagnoses reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome from other intracranial arteriopathies at admission.

creators.about_en: Aneesh B. Singhal, MD, is the vice-chair of quality and safety for the department of neurology and director of the Comprehensive Stroke Center at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He is also on the board of trustees of Spaulding Rehabilitation Hospital and the Mass General Brigham Continuing Care Network. Dr. Singhal's primary research is focused on the treatment of advanced stroke, imaging of acute stroke, and stroke present in young adults.
creators.name: Dr. Aneesh B. Singhal

creators.about_en: Eva A. Rocha, MD, PhD, completed this study as a neurology research fellow at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. She is now a practicing neurologist at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in Brazil and professor of Neurology at Centro Universitario São Camilo. Dr. Rocha's primary research is focused on the treatment of cerebrovascular diseases.
creators.name: Dr. Eva A. Rocha

cme_faq.answer: MDCalc’s Continuing Medical Education (CME) service allows users to easily earn AMA PRA Category 1 CreditsTM through regular use of MDCalc. Simply put, on top of getting the best medical calculators in the world, your usage will help you achieve your annual CME requirements, including specialty CME, without any extra effort.
cme_faq.question: What is MDCalc CME?

cme_faq.answer: Yes, in support of improving patient care, this activity has been planned and implemented by the Postgraduate Institute for Medicine and MDCalc Ltd. Inc. Postgraduate Institute for Medicine is jointly accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME), the Accreditation Council for Pharmacy Education (ACPE), and the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC), to provide continuing education for the healthcare team.
cme_faq.question: Is MDCalc CME accredited?

cme_faq.answer: Only United States attending physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and physician assistants are eligible for our CME service.
cme_faq.question: Who can enroll and how?

cme_faq.answer: We have over 275 CME-eligible calculators across various specialties. You can read the clinical content supporting any CME calculators to start earning. Once you have viewed all the supporting content for a calculator, you will have officially earned the credit amount (0.5 credits) and will be able to redeem a certificate. For now, only calc content in CME-eligible calcs is eligible for CME credits, however, we’ll be expanding our CME service to include more of our content in the future.
cme_faq.question: What activities can I do to earn CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: Simply use our search bar or visit our homepage to easily find CME-eligible calcs. You must be enrolled in our CME service to see which calcs are CME-eligible.
cme_faq.question: Where can I find calcs with which I can earn credits?

cme_faq.answer: Once you’ve enrolled in our CME service, you will have a personal CME Dashboard where you can view all of your earned credits. You can navigate to the dashboard by clicking the CME button in the header at the top of any page.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see which credits I’ve earned?

cme_faq.answer: Go to your CME Dashboard and select the credits you’d like to redeem, fill out a few dropdown answers about how you used the calc, and then proceed to checkout.
cme_faq.question: How do I redeem CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: No. Earning credits as you use calcs is free, but either you (or your employer) will need to purchase an annual subscription to redeem your CME certificates.
cme_faq.question: Are CME credits free?

cme_faq.answer: Just like with earned credits, you can view your CME certificates on your CME Dashboard in the “CME Certificates” tab. Certificates include a list of all of the calcs for which CME was earned along with a tally of the specialty CME.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see my CME certificates?

cme_faq.answer: One year from the date of purchase.
cme_faq.question: How long do credits in an annual subscription last?

cme_faq.answer: General; Addiction and Controlled Substances; Cardiac Care; Domestic and Intimate Partner Violence; Geriatrics; HIV and Infectious Disease; Hospice, End-of-Life, Terminal Illness, and Palliative Care; Mental and Behavioral Health; Pain Management; Pediatrics; Stroke; and Trauma.
cme_faq.question: What specialty CME credits are included in the plan?

cme_faq.answer:
Your gift card will be sent via email within 1-2 business days of making your purchase. You will be able to select from the following options - Visa, Amazon.com, Apple. Be sure to claim your gift card offer within 90 days of receiving the email.

Your CME purchase may have implications for tax reporting purposes. The cost of your CME product may or may not be tax-deductible when used for professional purposes. Any reimbursed amount for incentives must be declared as personal income for tax purposes. Please consult your tax advisor. MDCalc does not provide tax advice.
cme_faq.question: I ordered a CME package with a gift card. How does it work?

cme_faq.answer: Per the new guidelines from ACCME, the receipt will separate the cost you paid into the cost of the gift card and the cost of the CME learning activity.
cme_faq.question: What will show on my receipt for CME when it includes a gift card?

cme_faq.answer: You can get a refund (minus any promotional gift amount) within 30-days if the ease of earning and redeeming does not meet your expectations and if you have redeemed no more than 4 credits. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request a refund.
cme_faq.question: How do I get a refund if I'm not satisfied?

cme_faq.answer: You can upgrade your subscription throughout your billing cycle and pay the difference for a higher plan. You may request to downgrade your plan to a lower level to coincide with your next renewal. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request changes.
cme_faq.question: How do I later upgrade to a different plan if I need more credits?

cme_faq.answer: Gift card plans are available for 1 year and do not auto-renew. Standard, non gift-card subscriptions are auto-renewed annually. You can disable the automatic renewal of your subscription at any time by emailing team@mdcalc.com.
cme_faq.question: Do CME plans auto-renew?

cme_faq.answer: If you’re part of a team or practice that wants to sign up five or more physicians, please email us at team@mdcalc.com for more information.
cme_faq.question: How do I get information on a discounted bulk subscription program for my institution, team, or practice?

cme_faq.answer: On July 28, 2022, ACCME updated the guidelines regarding the use of high-value incentives. These guidelines allow for the use of gift card rewards in a regulated manner. Visit the ACCME website to read their guidelines.
cme_faq.question: Did the ACCME decide to regulate gift cards?
